descriptivenote.p: Collection material in English and Spanish

corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Manuscripts, correspondence, photographs, and audio recordings related to the New Mexico Folklife Project collection (AFC 1991/032) collected in 1984 and 1985.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: Laurie Beth Kalb Cosmo collection of New Mexico folklife documentation was processed by Valda Morris in 2023.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: New Mexico Folklife Project collection (AFC 1991/032). Laurie Beth Kalb Cosmo participated in the New Mexico Folklife Project as one of the interviewers. As a result, this collection has some items that may be exact duplicates from the original project. There are a few items that are labelled "copy" but there are other items that are not associated with any related materials. At this time it is difficult to compare versions. Please note the following recordings (SR10, SR12-SR18, and SR23) may be exact duplicates to New Mexico Folklife Project collection recordings .
Cosmo's original field documents and reports from the New Mexico Folklife Project collection are archived at the Museum of International Folk Art.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Laurie Beth Kalb Cosmo collection of New Mexico folklife documentation is open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Laurie Beth Kalb Cosmo collection of New Mexico folklife documentation (AFC 2022/001), American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Laurie Beth Kalb Cosmo is currently a lecturer at the University of Leiden University Center for the Arts in Society in the Netherlands. Before relocating to Europe, Cosmo was a folklorist who worked as a curator and museum administrator at several institutions and was the recipient of a number of fellowships and a Fulbright award.

In the 1980s, she participated in two projects where she worked alongside Carl Fleischhauer and Boyd Pratt in New Mexico. Cosmo documented the art of Hispanic carvers in northern New Mexico while working on the New Mexico Folklife Project. A year later she contributed to the survey of historic architecture in the northeastern quadrant of New Mexico.

Cosmo authored two books from the project,
Crafting Devotions: Tradition in Contemporary New Mexico Santos
and
Santos Statues & Sculpture: Contemporary Woodcarving from New Mexico
.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection includes manuscripts, correspondence, photographs, and audio recordings related to the New Mexico Folklife Project collection. Laurie Beth Kalb Cosmo represented the Museum of International Folk Art (Santa Fe) on the project and conducted fieldwork with Carl Fleischhauer, consultant, of the American Folklife Center. This collection includes fieldwork related to Cosmo's M.A. (1985) and Ph.D. (1992) theses at the University of Pennsylvania and other projects.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Laurie Beth Kalb Cosmo collection of New Mexico folklife documentation is organized in 3 series. Materials are arranged alphabetically within Series 1, Subseries 1; and chronologically within the remainder of the series.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: Chimayo, New Mexico

did.physdesc: manuscript materials, 8 black-and-white prints, and 1 color print

scopecontent.p: Includes interviews, correspondence, and articles pertaining to Lopez's life and his work in the Hispanic arts. His work was used in several exhibits and papers curated by Laurie Beth Kalb Cosmo. There is also a handwritten log and accompanying photographic prints of the Lopez family displaying some of their art, July 13, 1984.
Jose Benjamin Lopez field notes and correspondence.

scopecontent.p: Includes handwritten and typed interview notes, along with correspondence, articles, by laws of a Hispanic arts association, and a dissertation chapter draft on Luis' work. It also includes the planning of the exhibit which Tapia participated in at the Owings-Dewey Fine Art Gallery. Tapia has also participated in a number of exhibitions curated by Laurie Beth Kalb Cosmo. There are also photographic images of Tapia's work.
Includes interview with Luis Tapia. Also includes handwritten and typed field notes along with handwritten transcripts. Tapia's exhibit is also includes along with color prints of his art work.
Luis Tapia is a Santo maker from Santa Fe, New Mexico.
Luis Tapia is a Santo maker from Santa Fe, New Mexico.

scopecontent.p: Symposium at the Autry Museum of Western Heritage, Los Angeles. Includes paper that was presented, 29 color slides (35 mm), registration form and a brochure.

01:Santa Fe, Spanish market, 1884. Photo by D. Flynn 1, Thomas Sena?; 02: Leo Salazar and display on his woodcarvings at 1990 Spanish market; 03-04: unlabeled; 05: 5 "abstract;" 06-07: unlabeled; 08: Oviedo; 09 -28: unlabeled
Cosmo seeking permission to use The Merlan's family collection of Patrocinio Barela's materials for her dissertation.
Correspondence between Richard Ahlborn and Cosmo pertaining to her Smithsonian Fellowship. Also included is Cosmo's report of the fellowship.
Review of dissertation by Roger Abrahams, Charles Briggs and Burt Feintuch.
Article pertaining to Cosmo and her new position at the museum including congratulatory letters.
